title: 107_s3096
content: The Act is known as the "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" or the "BLAST Act". Its purposes are outlined in Section 2. The "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITION OF BALLISTICS. The term `ballistics' means a comparative analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to identify the firearm from which they were discharged. SEC. 4. TEST FIRING AND AUTOMATED STORAGE OF BALLISTICS RECORDS. Amendment to Section 923 of title 18, US Code requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, store records in a database, and keep fired bullet and cartridge casings. Licensed manufacturers or importers must test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, store records in a database, and keep fired bullet and cartridge casings as specified by the Secretary. This subsection does not create civil liability except for civil penalties. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist firearm manufacturers and importers in compliance. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with regulations by providing equipment, personnel, education, and coordination for ballistics imaging and crime reduction strategies. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for State and local law enforcement to access ballistics records promptly, as part of a comprehensive firearm crime reduction strategy. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for State and local law enforcement to access ballistics records promptly, as part of a comprehensive firearm crime reduction strategy. This includes encouraging training for all ballistics examiners. Additionally, they are required to submit an annual report to the Committee on the Judiciary regarding the impact of this section on Federal and State criminal investigations. The report will detail the impact of the section, including the number of criminal investigations aided by ballistics records, accessibility of records across jurisdictions, and evaluation of test programs under the Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act. The Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act authorizes funding for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and mandatory ballistics testing of firearms. $20,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2004 for these purposes. The Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act mandates ballistics testing of firearms by the Secretary and the Attorney General. The effective date depends on the interoperability certification of ballistics systems by the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury. The Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act requires mandatory ballistics testing of new firearms, with the effective date depending on the interoperability certification of ballistics systems by the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury. SEC. 5. PRIVACY RIGHTS OF LAW ABIDING CITIZENS. Ballistics information from this Act cannot be used for prosecution unless there is a reasonable belief of a crime and the information would help in the investigation.
